Tesla had been sourcing its servers exclusively from Super Micro, per Barclays Research in September 2023. But recent reports in May 2024 and posts by Elon Musk show Dell has now won major deals from Tesla, and Musk\u2019s xAI, eroding Super Micro\u2019s exclusivity. Super Micro has conceded that it is \u201Cunder-indexed\u201D with the world\u2019s largest technology companies, called \u201Chyperscalers.\u201D Amazon AWS was a customer but cut ties after delivery issues, per a former employee. Digital Ocean, a U.S. cloud service provider, switched from Super Micro to Dell after service issues, according to a Digital Ocean employee, describing the relationship as \u201Ca train wreck of sorts\u201D fraught with reliability issues. Genesis Cloud is touted as a \u201Csuccess story\u201D on Super Micro\u2019s website. But current and former employees told us otherwise: \u201CCatastrophic. It is, on the technical side, one of my worst experiences I\u2019ve had\u2026in the industry.\u201D GMI Cloud, a start-up GPU cloud provider in Asia and the U.S., told us they experienced a malfunction rate of 17.5% on its orders of 256 Super Micro servers. GMI is now moving away from Super Micro to HPE less than a year after its first order, per an employee. NexGen Cloud, an Nvidia partner, disclosed in October 2023 that it was investing $1 billion to build an AI super-cloud in Europe with over 20,000 Nvidia GPUs. But a NexGen employee told us that sometimes up to half of the orders received from Super Micro had firmware issues. Multiple former employees and channel partners confirmed that after-sales service is undermining Super Micro\u2019s ability to retain customers. One former salesperson said: \u201CIt\u2019s their Achilles heel. It\u2019s just horrible.\u201D All told, we believe Super Micro is a serial recidivist. It benefitted as an early mover but still faces significant accounting, governance and compliance issues and offers an inferior product and service now being eroded away by more credible competition."]})]}),(0,a.jsx)(m.li,{children:(0,a.jsx)(m.p,{children:"The only evidence of this is via a lawsuit by Bob K Huong detailed: 312345678910111213141516171819202122232425262728United States District CourtNorthern District of CaliforniaArbitration AgreementAs a condition of accepting and/or continuing employment with the Company, I agree to final and binding arbitration of Disputes between me and the Company, in accordance with the Arbitration of Disputes policy, the terms of which areincorporated by reference herein. I understand and agree that the Arbitration of Disputes policy (the terms of which control in the event of a conflict) requires arbitration of all Disputes which involvethe violation of my rights or the Company\u2019s rights arising from my employment or the termination of myemployment, including but not limited to violations of rights arising from employment discrimination and/orwrongfultermination of employment, breach of contract or other wrongful conduct, or breach of the Company\u2019spolicies, rights or contracts respecting confidential information and/or trade secrets. I understand andagree thatmy agreement to arbitrate Disputes means that I have voluntarily surrendered my rights to civil litigation and atrial by jury and any associated rights of appeal.Chan Decl. Ex. 2(Employee Acknowledgement Form).Plaintiff\u2019s signature appears immediately below this language. See id.Arbitration of Disputes PolicyThe Arbitration of Disputes policy(\u201CPolicy\u201D)referred toby and incorporated into the Employee Acknowledgement Formis contained in the SMCI employee handbook. SeeChan Decl. \xB6 6. ThePolicy, comprising 5 pages of the handbook, providesin relevant partthat\u201C[a]ll employees are required to agree to arbitrate Disputes (as described below) as a condition of employment\u201D with SMCI. Chan Decl. Ex. 3(Policy). \u201CCovered Disputes\u201D are defined to include \u201Cany complaint that there has been a violation\u201D of the employee\u2019s rights by SMCI or its officers, employees, or agents. Id.The Policy describes the procedure for requesting arbitration, and states that \u201C[a]ll questions concerning arbitrability, including but not limited to whether a party has anobligation to arbitrate a Dispute . . . shall be decided by a court not anarbitrator.\u201D Id.The employee \u201Cwill not be responsible for any part of the arbitrator\u2019s fees and costs.\u201D Id.The last paragraph of the policy, written in all capital letters and bolded, states:YOU UNDERSTAND THAT, BY ACCEPTING EMPLOYMENT AND/ORCONTINUING YOUR EMPLOYMENT WITH THE COMPANY, YOU AGREE TOEXCLUSIVE, FINAL AND BINDING ARBITRATION OF ANY COVERED DISPUTESBETWEEN YOU AND THE COMPANY IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE TERMS ANDCONDITIONS OF THIS POLICY, AND YOU VOLUNTARILY AGREE TOSURRENDER YOUR RIGHTS TO CIVIL LITIGATION AND A TRIAL BY JURY ANDANY ASSOCIATED RIGHTS OF APPEAL. 412345678910111213141516171819202122232425262728United States District CourtNorthern District of CaliforniaId.Present Lawsuitand Present MotionLuong filed the present lawsuit against SMCI and Liang on April 24, 2024, andfiled the operative FAC on May 6, 2024, asserting claims for retaliation underSOX, California Labor Code \xA71102.5, and FEHA. SeeCompl., ECF 1; FAC, ECF 6. Defendants requested that Luong agree to arbitrate his state law claimspursuant to the parties\u2019 written arbitration agreement, but Luong refused. SeeJordan Decl. \xB6\xB62-3. Defendants thereafter filed the present motion to compel arbitration of the state claim claims (Claims 2 and 3) and to stay this action, including the non-arbitrable SOX claim (Claim 1), pending completion of arbitration.II.LEGAL STANDARDThe Federal Arbitration Act (\u201CFAA\u201D) embodies a \u201Cnational policy favoring arbitration and a liberal federal policy favoring arbitration agreements, notwithstanding any state substantive or procedural policies to the contrary.\u201D AT&T Mobility, LLC v. Concepcion, 563 U.S. 333, 345-46 (2011) (internal quotationmarks and citations omitted).\u201CThe FAA, 9 U.S.C. \xA7 1 et seq., requires federal district courts to stay judicial proceedings and compel arbitration of claims covered by a written and enforceable arbitration agreement.\u201D Nguyen v. Barnes & Noble Inc., 763 F.3d 1171, 1175 (9th Cir. 2014).\u201CGenerally, in deciding whether to compel arbitration, a court must determine two \u2018gateway\u2019issues: (1) whether there is an agreement to arbitrate between the parties; and (2) whether the agreement covers the dispute.\u201D Brennan v. Opus Bank, 796 F.3d 1125, 1130 (9th Cir. 2015). The first of these issues is non-delegable and must be decided by the district court. See Ahlstrom v. DHI Mortg. Co., Ltd., L.P., 21 F.4th 631, 635 (9th Cir. 2021) (\u201C[P]arties cannot delegate issues of formation to the arbitrator.\u201D).The second issue is presumptively reserved for the court, but the parties may agree to delegate it to the arbitrator.See id.at 634; see alsoPortland Gen. Elec. Co. v. Liberty Mut. Ins. Co., 862 F.3d 981, 985 (9th Cir. 2017)(\u201C[W]hether an arbitration clause in a concededly binding contract applies to a given controversy\u201D is \u201Cpresumptively reserved for the court\u201D unless the parties clearly and unmistakably delegate that issue to the arbitrator). 512345678910111213141516171819202122232425262728United States District CourtNorthern District of CaliforniaIII.DISCUSSIONAs noted above, Luong asserts a single federal claim for retaliation under SOX (Claim 1) and two state law claims for retaliation under California Labor Code \xA71102.5 and FEHA (Claims 2 and3).The SOX claim is asserted against both SMCI and Liang. However, the parties agree that the SOX claim cannot be compelled to arbitration. See18 U.S.C. \xA7 1514A(e)(2) (\u201CNo predispute arbitration provision shall be valid or enforceable, if the agreement requires arbitration of a dispute arising under this section.\u201D).The state law claims are asserted against only SMCI. Defendants move to compel arbitration of the state law claims, arguing that Luong and SMCI entered into an arbitration agreement that is governed by the FAA, the arbitration agreement is enforceable, and the state law claims fall within the scope of the arbitration agreement. Defendants move to stay this litigation, including the SOX claim, pending arbitration of the state law claims.Luong does not dispute that the asserted arbitration agreement is governed by the FAA, as \u201C[e]mployment contracts, except for those covering workers engaged in transportation, are covered by the FAA.\u201D See E.E.O.C. v. Waffle House, Inc., 534 U.S. 279, 289 (2002). Nor does Luong dispute that hisstate law claims fall within the scope of the asserted arbitration agreement.However, he contends that the arbitration agreement is unenforceable on the grounds that it is unconscionable and that it violates SOX.He further contends that even if the Court grants Defendants\u2019 motion to compel arbitration of the state law claims, the Court should deny Defendants\u2019 motion to stay with respect to the SOX claim and instead allow the SOX claim to proceed in this Court. A.Luong and SMCIEntered into an Arbitration AgreementIn determining whether an arbitration agreement exists, a district court applies \u201Cordinary state-law principles that govern the formation of contracts.\u2019\u201DReichert v. Rapid Invs., Inc., 56 F.4th 1220, 1227(9th Cir. 2022)(internal quotation marks and citation omitted).Under California law, an arbitration agreement generally must be memorialized in writing. See Pinnacle Museum Tower Assn. v. Pinnacle Mkt. Dev. (US), LLC, 55 Cal. 4th 223, 236 (2012). \u201CA party\u2019s acceptance of an agreement to arbitrate may be express, as where a party signs the agreement,\u201D or the party\u2019s 612345678910111213141516171819202122232425262728United States District CourtNorthern District of Californiaacceptance may be implied in fact. Id.\u201CAn arbitration clause within a contract may be binding on a party even if the party never actually read the clause.\u201D Id.\u201CThe party seeking arbitration bears the burden of proving the existence of an arbitration agreement, and the party opposing arbitration bears the burden of proving any defense, such as unconscionability.\u201D Id.SMCI submitsthe following documents:a copy of the offer letter signed by Luong, acknowledging that his offer of employment was contingent on his signing all required employment documents, including documents containingan arbitration agreement, seeChan Decl. \xB6 3 & Ex. 1 (Offer Letter); a copy of theEmployee Acknowledgement Form signed by Luong, expressly agreeing to final and binding arbitration of disputes with SMCI as a condition of his employment, seeChan Decl. \xB6 5 & Ex. 2 (Employee Acknowledgement Form); and a copy of the Arbitration of Disputes policy contained in the employee handbook and incorporated into the Employee Acknowledgement Form, Chan Decl. Ex. 3 (Policy). This evidence satisfies Defendants\u2019 burden to prove the existence of an arbitration agreement between Luong and SMCI. Luong does not dispute signing the offer letter or Employee Acknowledgement Form. He submits a declaration statement that he \u201Cwas not provided with the employee handbook containing the Arbitration of Disputes Policy referenced in the purported arbitration agreement and was not aware of the terms contained therein prior to signing the purported arbitration agreement.\u201D Luong Decl. \xB64, ECF 23-1. This statement is insufficient to undermine Defendants\u2019 showing that the parties entered into an arbitration agreement, as the Employee Acknowledgement Form signed by Luong states expressly that Luong did receive the Arbitration of Disputes policy and agreed to be bound by it. See Pinnacle, 55 Cal. 4th at 236(\u201CAn arbitration clause within a contract may be binding on a party even if the party never actually read the clause.\u201D); see also Sanchez v. Valencia Holding Co., LLC, 61 Cal. 4th 899, 915 (2015) (rejecting argument that plaintiff did not read arbitration clause, observing that \u201Cit is generally unreasonable . . . to neglect to read a written contract before signing it\u201D).B.The Arbitration Agreement is EnforceableIf the party seeking arbitration meets its burden to prove the existence of an arbitration agreement, the party opposing arbitration bears the burden to prove any defense.See Pinnacle, 55 712345678910111213141516171819202122232425262728United States District CourtNorthern District of CaliforniaCal. 4th at 236. Luong argues that the arbitration agreement is unenforceable because it is unconscionable and because it violates SOX. Neither argument is meritorious.1.Unconscionability\u201C[G]enerally applicable contract defenses, such as . . . unconscionability, may be applied to invalidate arbitration agreements without contravening the FAA or California law.\u201D OTO, L.L.C. v. Kho, 8 Cal. 5th 111, 125 (2019) (internal quotation marks and citation omitted, alterations in original). \u201CBoth procedural and substantive unconscionability must be shown for the defense to be established[.]\u201D Id.\u201CThe procedural element addresses the circumstances of contract negotiation and formation, focusing onoppression or surprise due to unequal bargaining power.\u201D Id.(internal quotation marks and citation omitted). \u201CSubstantive unconscionability pertains to the fairness of an agreement\u2019s actual terms and to assessments of whether they are overly harsh or one-sided.\u201DId.(internal quotation marks and citation omitted). \u201CThe burden of proving unconscionability rests upon the party asserting it.\u201D Id.at 126. Luong asserts that the procedural unconscionability requirement is met because he was required to sign the Employee Acknowledgement Form containing the arbitration agreementas a condition of employment, and because the Arbitration of Disputes policy was \u201Cburied\u201D in the employee handbook and \u201Cmerely incorporated by reference\u201D into the Employee Acknowledgement Form. Taking those arguments in reverse order, the Court finds Luong\u2019s characterization of the arbitration policy as \u201Cburied\u201D in the employee handbook to be inaccurate. The policy is 5 pages in length, contains subheadings that make its various provisions easyto access, and concludes with a bolded paragraph written in all capital letters that unequivocally provides for binding arbitration. The 1-page Employee Acknowledgement Form calls out the key aspects of the arbitration agreement, specifically that it is a condition of employment and encompasses all disputes arising out of employment or termination of employment. Given Luong\u2019s signature on the 1-page Employee Acknowledgement Form directly above the paragraph addressing arbitration, his assertion that he did not have notice of thatterm of employment is wholly unpersuasive.Moreover, that fact that the arbitration agreementwas a condition of employment does not render it procedurally unconscionable. \u201CArbitration contracts imposed as a condition of 812345678910111213141516171819202122232425262728United States District CourtNorthern District of Californiaemployment are typically adhesive.\u201D OTO, 8 Cal. 5th at 126. \u201CThe pertinent question, then, is whether circumstances of the contract\u2019s formation created such oppression or surprise that closer scrutiny of its overall fairness is required.\u201D Id.\u201CThe circumstances relevant to establishing oppression include, but are not limited to (1) the amount of time the party is given to consider the proposed contract; (2) the amount and type of pressure exerted on the party to sign the proposed contract; (3) the length of the proposed contract and the length and complexity of the challenged provision; (4) the education and experience of the party; and (5) whether the party\u2019s review of the proposed contract was aided by an attorney.\u201DId.at 126-27. Luong had more than a week between the date the offer of employment was extended, December 19, 2012, and the date he accepted, December 28, 2012. There is no evidence that any pressure was exerted on him to sign the offer letter and Employee Acknowledgement Form. The offerletter is 2 pages in length and the Employee Acknowledgement Form containing the arbitration agreement is 1 page in length. Luong is an educated, sophisticated individual who accepted a position with a base salary of $170,000. It is unclear whether Luong engaged an attorney to help him review the proposed contract, but he certainly had the opportunity to do so. Based on this record, the Court finds that Luong has failed to carry his burden of proving procedural unconscionability.Nor has Luong proved substantive unconscionability.\u201CIn evaluating substantive unconscionability, courts often look to whether the arbitration agreement meets certain minimum levels of fairness.\u201D Murrey v. Superior Ct., 87 Cal. App. 5th 1223, 1247-48 (2023). \u201C[A]t a minimum, a mandatory employment arbitration agreement must (1) provide for neutral arbitrators, (2) provide for more than minimal discovery, (3) require a written award that permits limited judicial review, (4) provide for all of the types of relief that would otherwise be available in court, and (5) require the employer to pay the arbitrator\u2019s fees and all costs unique to arbitration.\u201D Id.(citation omitted). Luong argues that the arbitration agreement at issue heredoes not provide for adequate discoveryand may require him to pay costs unique to arbitration, such asDefendants\u2019 costs incurred in responding to his discovery requestsand administrative and facility fees.The California Supreme Court has rejected the notion that anarbitration agreementis unconscionable merely because it grants the arbitrator discretion over what discovery may be taken. See 912345678910111213141516171819202122232425262728United States District CourtNorthern District of CaliforniaArmendariz v. Found. Health Psychcare Servs., Inc., 24 Cal. 4th 83, 105 & n.10 (2000). With respect to the costs of arbitration, the Arbitration of Disputes policy states that the employee \u201Cwill not be responsible for any part of the arbitrator\u2019s fees and costs.\u201D Chan Decl. Ex. 3 (Policy). The policy does require that each side pay its own discovery costs, as is customary in litigation. See id.The Court does not read the policy to require Luong to pay Defendants\u2019 costs in responding to discovery requests, or any costs that are unique to arbitration, and Luong has not pointed to any provision of the policy clearly imposing such costs on him.The reliance Luong places on Ronderos v. USF Reddaway, Inc., 114 F.4th 1080 (9th Cir. 2024), and similar cases is misplaced, as those cases involved unsophisticated individuals in factual circumstances dissimilar to this case. See, e.g., Ronderos, 114 F.4th 1080 (applicant for position of line haul manager pushed to sign agreement immediately and on site); OTO, 8 Cal. 5th 111 (agreement presented to low level worker at his workspace with expectation that he sign it immediately).2.Asserted Violation of SOXLuong contends that the arbitration agreement is unenforceable because it encompasses all claims arising out of his employment, including his SOX claim, and thus runs afoul of SOX\u2019s prohibition against arbitration agreements. The relevant provision of SOX reads as follows: \u201CNo predispute arbitration agreement shall be valid or enforceable, if the agreement requires arbitration of a dispute arising under this section.\u201D 18 U.S.C.A. \xA7 1514A(e)(2).According to Luong, that provision invalidates the arbitration agreementat issue hereentirely, with respect to bothhisSOX claim and his non-SOX claims.Luong relies on out-of-circuit decisions from the District of Puerto Ricoand the Western District of Arkansas to support his position. See Stewart v. Doral Fin. Corp., 997 F. Supp. 2d 129 (D.P.R. 2014); Laubenstein v. Conair Corp., No. 5:14-CV-05227, 2014 WL 6609164(W.D. Ark. Nov. 19, 2014). Those decisions applied \xA71514A(e)(2) to invalidate arbitration agreements as to both SOX claims and non-SOX claims where the claims arose from the same facts, reasoning that under those circumstances allowing arbitration of the non-SOX claims would frustrate the purpose of \xA71514A(e)(2). 1012345678910111213141516171819202122232425262728United States District CourtNorthern District of CaliforniaDefendants arguethat Luong\u2019s reading of the SOX prohibition against arbitration agreements is too broad, relying primarily on a California district court decision thatrejected the approach of Stewartand Laubenstein. See Endresen v. Banc of California, Inc., No. SACV 18-00899-CJC(DFMx), 2018 WL 11399501, at *3 (C.D. Cal. Sept. 20, 2018). The Endresencourt emphasized that the prohibition on arbitration set forth in \xA71514A(e)(2)is expressly limited to claims arising under SOX, and that \u201C[d]enying arbitration on some claims because there are also non-arbitrable claims ignores the FAA\u2019s \u2018emphatic federal policy\u2019in favor of arbitration.\u201D Id.The Endresencourt acknowledged that the FAAmay be overridden by a clear congressional command,but concluded that SOX does not contain a clear congressional mandate that would extend \xA71514A(e)(2)beyond the scope of claims brought under SOX. See id.This Court agrees with the reasoning of Endresen, specifically the conclusion that it would be improper to refuse to enforce a valid arbitration agreement as required under the FAA, absent a clear congressional mandate. In this Court\u2019s view, a judicial determination that the purpose of SOX\u2019s anti-arbitration provision might be frustrated by compelling arbitration of non-SOX claims arising from the same facts is an insufficient basis to override the FAA. Moreover, this Court agrees with the Endresencourt\u2019s observation that \u201Cit is not clear why arbitration of non-SOX claims would frustrate any purpose of section 1514A, since Plaintiff\u2019s SOX claim still remains before the court.\u201D Endresen, 2018 WL 11399501, at *3C.The State Law Claims Fall Within the Scope of the Arbitration AgreementThere is no dispute that Luong\u2019s state law claims for retaliation, which clearly arise out of his employment and termination, fall within the scope of the arbitration agreement, and the Court finds that the state law claims do fall within the scope of theagreement. Accordingly, the Court will grant Defendants\u2019 motion to compel arbitration of Luong\u2019s state law claims.D.A Stay of this Action, Including theSOX Claim, is WarrantedDefendants move to stay this action, including the SOX claim, pending arbitration of the state law claims.Luong opposes a stay of litigation of his SOX claim, asking the Court to allow his SOX claim to proceed in this forum while his state law claims proceed in arbitration.Where a complaint asserts both arbitrable and non-arbitrable claims, the defendants are not 1112345678910111213141516171819202122232425262728United States District CourtNorthern District of Californiaentitled to a stay of the non-arbitrable claims as of right, but the district court may in its discretion stay the non-arbitrable claims \u201Cunder the powers to control its own docket and to provide for the prompt and efficient determination of the cases pending before it.\u201D Leyva v. Certified Grocers of California, Ltd., 593 F.2d 857, 863 (9th Cir. 1979). \u201CA stay should not be granted unless it appears likely the other proceedings will be concluded within a reasonable time in relation to the urgency of the claims presented to the court.\u201D Id.at 864. In Leyva, the Ninth Circuit found that \u201C[i]t would waste judicial resources and be burdensome upon the parties if the district court in a case such as this were mandated to permit discovery, and upon completion of pretrial proceedings, to take evidence and determine the merits of the case at the same time as the arbitrator is going through a substantially parallel process.\u201D Id.Other courts in this district have found it appropriate to stay a SOX claim pending arbitration of non-SOX claims arising from the same facts. See, e.g., Anderson v. Salesforce.com, Inc., No. 18-CV-06712-PJH, 2018 WL 6728015, at *3 (N.D. Cal. Dec. 21, 2018). The Andersoncourt found it \u201Cappropriate to stay plaintiff\u2019s SOX claim and the entire action because plaintiff\u2019s claims all arise from the same conduct and because allowing the arbitration to resolve will simplify issues of law or questions of fact in future proceedings.\u201D Id.As in Anderson, Luong\u2019snon-arbitrable SOX claim and arbitrable state law claims arise from the same conduct, and staying litigation of the SOX claim pending arbitration of the state law claims may simplify questions of fact and/or issues of law in future proceedings. Luongargues that such simplification would prejudice his ability to litigate his SOX claim, because discovery in the arbitration will be far more limited than discovery available in district court. He asserts that there is a substantial risk that his SOX claim will be subject to issue preclusion arising from an adverse arbitration decision on the non-SOX claims. Luong urgesthe Court to deny the requested stay of the SOX claim, citing an out-of-circuitdecision in which the court found it appropriate toallow the SOX claim to be litigated in parallel with arbitration of the non-SOX claims. See Vuoncino v. Forterra, Inc., No. 3:21-CV-01046-K, 2022 WL 868274, at *8 (N.D. Tex. Feb. 28, 2022), report and recommendation adopted, No. 3:21-CV-01046-K, 2022 WL 865893 (N.D. Tex. Mar. 22, 2022). 1212345678910111213141516171819202122232425262728United States District CourtNorthern District of CaliforniaWhile Luong\u2019s prejudice argumenthas some facial appeal, he has not demonstrated that he is likely to be prejudiced by any limitations in the arbitration proceeding. His prejudice argument is premised on the assumption that he will not prevail in arbitration,and thus will be denied a fair opportunity to litigate his SOX claim because he will be bound by an adverse arbitration decision based on limited discovery. Luong\u2019s apparent assumption that he will lose at arbitration is not founded on any record evidence. Moreover, when the Court inquired at the hearing whether the arbitrator\u2019s decision onthenon-SOX claims would be binding on this Court during subsequent litigation of the SOX claim, Luong\u2019s counsel was unable to direct the Court to any controlling authority. Accordingly, the Court finds Luong\u2019s argument of prejudice to be purely speculative. The Court in the exercise of its discretion finds that a stay of this litigation, including the SOX claim, is warranted for reasons of economy and efficiency. Luong\u2019s SOX claim arises from the same facts as his non-SOX claims,and under those circumstances allowing this case to proceed in parallel to the arbitration likely would result in a waste of judicial resources and imposition of an undue burden on Defendants. Important to this decision is the representation of Defendants\u2019 counsel at the hearing that the parties are poised to commence arbitration as soon as the Court issues its ruling. The Court will require the parties to begin arbitration within 60 days after this order.IV.ORDER(1) Defendants\u2019 motion to compel arbitration and stay action is GRANTED. Plaintiff\u2019s state law claims (Claims 2 and 3) are hereby COMPELLED to arbitration. This action, including Plaintiff\u2019s SOX claim (Claim 1), is STAYED pending arbitrationof the state law claims.(2)The parties SHALL commence arbitration within 60 days after the date of this order and SHALL file a joint status report byFebruary 3, 2025,advising the Court of the status of arbitration.(3)This order terminates ECF 17.Dated:November 4, 202"})}),(0,a.jsx)(m.li,{children:(0,a.jsxs)(m.p,{children:["Justice Department Probes Server Maker Super Micro Computer Super Micro Computer, the server maker that saw its business take off with the artificial-intelligence boom, is being probed by the Justice Department following a critical report by an activist short-selling firm, according to people familiar with the matter. The probe is at an early stage, the people said. A prosecutor at the U.S. attorney\u2019s office in San Francisco recently has contacted people potentially holding relevant information. The prosecutor asked for information that appeared to be connected to a former employee who accused the company of accounting violations. The former employee filed a whistleblower lawsuit in April against Super Micro and its chief executive. A Super Micro spokesman declined to comment, as did a spokesman for the U.S. attorney\u2019s office. Short seller Hindenburg Research published its report about Super Micro on Aug. 27, and said it had placed bets against the company\u2019s stock. The report focused in part on allegations made by the former employee, Bob Luong, as well as transactions between Super Micro and companies run by family members of its chief executive, Charles Liang. Shares of Super Micro surged with the bull market in AI-themed stocks. The company, commonly known as Supermicro, makes specialized servers that use the chips Nvidia designs for generative AI. The stock rose 14-fold from the start of 2023 through March and has since tumbled 59%. At its peak, the company was worth ",(0,a.jsxs)(m.span,{className:"katex",children:[(0,a.jsx)(m.span,{className:"katex-mathml",children:(0,a.jsx)(m.math,{xmlns:"http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML",children:(0,a.jsxs)(m.semantics,{children:[(0,a.jsxs)(m.mrow,{children:[(0,a.jsx)(m.mn,{children:"66"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.mi,{children:"b"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.mi,{children:"i"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.mi,{children:"l"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.mi,{children:"l"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.mi,{children:"i"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.mi,{children:"o"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.mi,{children:"n"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.mi,{mathvariant:"normal",children:"."}),(0,a.jsx)(m.mi,{children:"S"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.mi,{children:"u"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.mi,{children:"p"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.mi,{children:"e"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.mi,{children:"r"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.mi,{children:"M"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.mi,{children:"i"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.mi,{children:"c"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.mi,{children:"r"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.mi,{children:"o"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.mi,{children:"i"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.mi,{children:"n"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.mn,{children:"2020"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.mi,{children:"p"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.mi,{children:"a"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.mi,{children:"i"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.mi,{children:"d"})]}),(0,a.jsx)(m.annotation,{encoding:"application/x-tex",children:"66 billion. Super Micro in 2020 paid "})]})})}),(0,a.jsx)(m.span,{className:"katex-html","aria-hidden":"true",children:(0,a.jsxs)(m.span,{className:"base",children:[(0,a.jsx)(m.span,{className:"strut",style:{height:".8889em",verticalAlign:"-.1944em"}}),(0,a.jsx)(m.span,{className:"mord",children:"66"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.span,{className:"mord mathnormal",children:"bi"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.span,{className:"mord mathnormal",style:{marginRight:".01968em"},children:"ll"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.span,{className:"mord mathnormal",children:"i"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.span,{className:"mord mathnormal",children:"o"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.span,{className:"mord mathnormal",children:"n"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.span,{className:"mord",children:"."}),(0,a.jsx)(m.span,{className:"mord mathnormal",style:{marginRight:".05764em"},children:"S"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.span,{className:"mord mathnormal",children:"u"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.span,{className:"mord mathnormal",children:"p"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.span,{className:"mord mathnormal",style:{marginRight:".02778em"},children:"er"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.span,{className:"mord mathnormal",style:{marginRight:".10903em"},children:"M"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.span,{className:"mord mathnormal",children:"i"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.span,{className:"mord mathnormal",children:"cro"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.span,{className:"mord mathnormal",children:"in"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.span,{className:"mord",children:"2020"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.span,{className:"mord mathnormal",children:"p"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.span,{className:"mord mathnormal",children:"ai"}),(0,a.jsx)(m.span,{className:"mord mathnormal",children:"d"})]})})]}),"17.5 million to settle Securities and Exchange Commission claims of widespread accounting violations, without admitting or denying the accusations. The SEC also reached a settlement with a former Super Micro chief financial officer, and it required Liang to reimburse the company $2.1 million in stock-sale profits even though it didn\u2019t accuse Liang of misconduct. In his lawsuit, Luong said Super Micro fired several employees associated with the past accounting violations, only to hire them back later. Hindenburg highlighted the same point in its report. Hindenburg also said it had found instances of Super Micro products being shipped to companies in Russia after the war in Ukraine began, despite U.S. sanctions. On Aug. 28, the day after the Hindenburg report, Super Micro said it would be late filing its fiscal 2024 annual report with the SEC. The company soon afterward said its board of directors had formed a committee \u201Cto review certain of the company\u2019s internal controls and other matters.\u201D The company still hasn\u2019t filed its annual report. In a Sept. 3 letter to customers, Liang said the short-seller report \u201Ccontains false or inaccurate statements about our company,\u201D and that \u201Cwe will address these statements in due course.\u201D Liang said the company didn\u2019t anticipate making any significant changes in its previously released financial results for fiscal 2024. Luong in his lawsuit alleged Super Micro in some instances recognized revenue improperly from fiscal 2020 to 2022. He said in some cases it booked revenue on sales that hadn\u2019t been completed. He said another method for booking revenue prematurely \u201Cwas to ship and bill certain customers for incomplete equipment that was not ready for sale.\u201D Luong said Super Micro fired him in April 2023, after placing him on unpaid leave months earlier. His last job there was as a general manager responsible for providing leadership and guidance for Super Micro\u2019s global service team. Super Micro has asked the court to put Luong\u2019s lawsuit on hold and send his claims to arbitration. A hearing on the company\u2019s request is scheduled for Thursday. Tanya Gomerman, an attorney for Luong, said in a statement, \u201CMr. Luong came forward to report what he believed were significant accounting irregularities, and instead of taking steps to investigate or fix these problems they terminated him and swept the matter under the rug.\u201D"]})}),(0,a.jsx)(m.li,{children:(0,a.jsx)(m.p,{children:"Supermicro denies wrongdoing, despite the DoJ probe (Bloomberg) -- Super Micro Computer Inc. said an independent review of its business found no evidence of misconduct but recommended that the server maker appoint new top financial and legal leadership. A review by a special board committee, alongside attorneys from Cooley LLP and forensic accounting firm Secretariat Advisors, found \u201Cno evidence of misconduct on the part of management or the board of directors and that the audit committee acted independently.\u201D As a result of the findings, the committee recommended Super Micro install a new chief financial officer, chief compliance officer, and general counsel, it said in a statement Monday. \u201CThe board has instructed management to add additional experienced, senior talent commensurate with the Company\u2019s size and complexity today and to prepare for its future growth,\u201D Super Micro said in the statement. The shares jumped as much as 22.5% on Monday in New York. Super Micro does not expect changes to previously issued financial results for the most recent fiscal year, it said. Kenneth Cheung, formerly vice president of finance, will be the company\u2019s new chief accounting officer. And the company has begun the process to search for a new CFO to replace David Weigand. It\u2019s been a tumultuous year for Super Micro. The maker of high-powered servers missed an August deadline to file its annual financial report and its auditor, Ernst & Young LLP, resigned in October, citing concerns about the company\u2019s governance and transparency. The company is also facing a US Department of Justice probe following a damaging report from short seller Hindenburg Research. EY communicated concerns to Super Micro\u2019s audit committee in July. In response, the board investigated revenue recognition practices, export control policies, the rehiring of employees who had resigned following earlier accounting issues, and disclosure of related party transactions. The investigation determined that \u201Cthe conclusions EY stated in its resignation letter were not supported by the facts examined in the review.\u201D In November, Super Micro appointed BDO USA as its independent auditor and submitted a plan to come into compliance with Nasdaq listing requirements. Completing the internal investigation clears a major hurdle to filing its audited financials, wrote Woo Jin Ho, an analyst at Bloomberg Intelligence. When investigating the rehiring of nine individuals who had resigned from the company following a 2017 investigation, the special committee found that the decisions to rehire were \u201Cthe product of reasonable business judgment.\u201D Still, there were lapses \u201Cin ensuring guardrails were always in place and observed,\u201D the special committee found. That includes not informing EY before entering into a consulting arrangement with Super Micro\u2019s former CFO, who had resigned following the 2017 investigation. That arrangement has since been terminated. Chief Financial Officer David Weigand held \u201Cprimary responsibility\u201D for these lapses, the committee found. He will continue to serve as the Company\u2019s CFO until the board has named his successor, Super Micro said. The committee found \u201Cno evidence indicating that any process lapse resulted from bad faith, improper motives, or lack of regard for accurate financial reporting or compliance.\u201D In 2020, Super Micro paid $17.5 million to resolve a US Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into its financial accounting and disclosures for fiscal years 2014 through 2017. Super Micro didn\u2019t admit to or deny the regulator\u2019s allegations as part of its settlement. In addition to appointing new financial and legal leadership, the company will improve its training related to sales and revenue recognition policies. The investigation involved analysis of over 9 million documents and 68 witness interviews, Super Micro said. It also included \u201Cextensive meetings\u201D with Deloitte & Touche LLP and EY, the company\u2019s former auditors."})})]})]})}function o(e={}){let{wrapper:m}=e.components||{};return m?(0,a.jsx)(m,{...e,children:(0,a.jsx)(d,{...e})}):d(e)}return b(v);})();

toc.value: Based on the following information, estimate the probability that Supermicro will fail to meet the late February deadline for their 10-K report?
How did supermicro get in this situation

document.title: Will Joe Rogan interview Trump before the election?

body.raw:
# Intro
Earlier this month, Elon posted on twitter "it will happen", in response to a post asking whether or not Rogan would have Trump on his podcast.

After consulting some people, I decided to bet against it on Polymarket.

### Analysis
Let's think about this in terms conditional probability before we get into the less systematic reasons

Premise 1: Rogan is only interested in real long form (>3 hour) real discussion with pushback, not a rehearsed political interview. So no vetted questions or editing.

Premise 2: Rogan would not accept a shorter less conversational (lex style) interveiw that went against P1

Premise 3: Trump and his team are not comfortable with an unedited 3-hour interview with Rogan with pushback and challenging conversations where trump wouldnt be able to raillroad convos (like in the lex or theo von appearances)

Conclusion: Therefore, Joe Rogan will not interview Trump before the 2024 election, now 18 days away.


Premise 1 can be evidenced by Rogan's statements (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MSSF0pyJpsY), personality, ect. It's clear to me that he does NOT want a low-quality interivew.
This logic can also apply to Premise 2, unless Rogan has a change of heart in a small amount of time. This also seems unlikely because his podcast with Trump would be his most popular.

Premise 3 This can be evidenced by Trump's previous podcast appearances (e.g., Lex Fridman, Theo Von), where he often avoids answering tough policy questions and instead focuses on more personal or non-political topics to humanize himself. 
In a video, Rogan mentions he would need to have "hard conversations" with Trump if an episode were to happen, which doesn't align with Trump's media strategy or messaging control.

Joe has also in previous episodes expressed that he would be uncomfortable having such an impact on the election as he does not feel it is his place. He has also implied to not being truly on board with the  Trump train and Trumps personality.
**It is impossible then, for Premise 1 to coexist with Premise 3.**

Along the lines of p3, we have to question what real benefit Trump gains from appearing on the Joe Rogan Experience (JRE). 
Rogan's primary audience consists of males, many of whom are likely already part of Trump's base—predominantly white, male, and middle-aged (we dont even have to mention that the avg jre listener is a trump supporter). 
Joe having a hard conversation poking holes in the trumps policy and charactar will likely only have negative implications. 
Despite a Trump appearance on Joe Rogan's show likely being mostly positive in terms of audience reception there is just very little upside given the risk of being challenged on tougher topics which may outweigh the minimal benefits of preaching to the choir.


As a result, it is unlikely **(~20% probability)** that Trump will interview Rogan.

It should be noted that Trump and Elon's statements do not reflect Rogan's personal views. Elon, being on the spectrum, may exaggerate his influence on Rogan, and Trump himself does not know whether or not he is
doing the interview. In fact, his camp has been declining interviews more [frequently as of late](https://www.politico.com/live-updates/2024/10/18/2024-elections-live-coverage-updates-analysis/trump-skips-another-interview-00184327).

structuredData.headline: Will Joe Rogan interview Trump before the election?

body.raw:
My strategy is insanely risky, involving very concentrated leveraged bets and strong psychological discipline.

It's gotten to the point where I don't even like talking to people about it... because my entire life is on a single bet.

I've lost ~70% of my portfolio several times, with my worst drawdown being in 2024 (lost 78% of portfolio from peak to trough)

In terms of gains up till now, I am a substantially over my starting amount (I think about 150% NW increase accounting for expenses)

No tweets, little discussion, ect. I rarely even talk about specific investments when the stock market comes up with someone.

I'll just tell them to invest in diversified portfolio of index funds, bank stocks, dividend stocks, ect.
